member.name: T:BaseAction
member.summary: A BaseAction object is the basic action object. There is one of these automatically created for each 'KSPAction' field in a partModule

member.name: F:BaseAction.actionGroup
member.summary: Bitmap of the action groups this action is currently assigned to. Example:

member.name: F:BaseAction.active
member.summary:
Is this action available? Setting this false disables the action so it will not show in the available actions list.
Note this totally disables the action, even calling it in code will not execute the action if this bool is false. (As of KSP 0.90, assumed still true in KSP 1.1)

member.name: F:BaseAction.defaultActionGroup
member.summary:
Assign this action to action groups upon creation ('Gear' group for landing legs)
Set the default group to Brakes only:
member.remarks: Add the Custom01 group to the default groups.

Note this value is only used when a part is placed in the editor and the values in defaultActionGroup are transferred to actionGroup at that time. Once a part is placed in the editor (or in flight mode) use the actionGroup object instead.

member.name: F:BaseAction.guiName
member.summary: Name shown in editor action groups panel, can safely be edited as any other string.

member.name: F:BaseAction.listParent
member.summary: Information about what the action is attached to. listParent.module = partModule this action is a memeber of listParent.part = part this action is a member of

member.name: F:BaseAction.name
member.summary: Name of the action group as seen in code where the KSPAction field exists. Do not edit, this is the identifier of the action as used in code and is not player visible. (See guiName for what is visible in game.)

member.name: M:BaseAction.Invoke(KSPActionParam)
member.summary: Activate this action. Note that there is no toggle activation, you must check state yourself in code and activate or deactivate as appropriate **Example code start to activate an action: KSP version 0.24.2**
member.code: KSPActionParam actParam = new KSPActionParam(KSPActionGroup.None, KSPActionType.Activate); //okay to create this new just before invoking exampleAction.Invoke(actParam); //action defined as a KSPAction in a partModule
member.remarks: **Example code start to deactivate an action: KSP version 0.24.2**
member.code: KSPActionParam actParam = new KSPActionParam(KSPActionGroup.None, KSPActionType.Deactivate); //okay to create this new just before invoking exampleAction.Invoke(actParam); //action defined as a KSPAction in a partModule

member.name: T:CelestialBody
member.summary: The Sun, the planets, and the moons are all CelestialBodies.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.angularV
member.summary: The magnitude of the angular velocity of the body's rotation, in radians per second.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.angularVelocity
member.summary: The body's angular velocity vector, in rotations per second. This points along the axis of rotation and its magnitude is the rotation rate in radians per second.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.atmosphere
member.summary: Whether this body has an atmosphere

member.name: F:CelestialBody.atmosphereContainsOxygen
member.summary: Presumably, whether jet engines will work in this body's atmosphere

member.name: F:CelestialBody.bodyName
member.summary: The name of the body, as a string.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.GeeASL
member.summary: The gravitational acceleration of the body at sea level, in units of gees (1 gee = 9.81 m/s^2)

member.name: F:CelestialBody.gMagnitudeAtCenter
member.summary: The gravitational acceleration (in m/s^2) at a radius r (in m) from the body's center is gMagnitudeAtCenter / r^2

member.name: F:CelestialBody.gravParameter
member.summary: The gravitational parameter GM is the universal gravitational constant G times the mass M of the body. In KSP the gravitational constant G is exactly 6.673 m^3 / (kg s^2), and the body mass is measured in kilograms.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.hillSphere
member.summary: Unused?

member.name: F:CelestialBody.Mass
member.summary: The mass of the body in kilograms. Computed

member.name: F:CelestialBody.ocean
member.summary: Whether this planet has an ocean at "sea level"

member.name: F:CelestialBody.orbitDriver
member.summary: this is what gives the celestial body its orbit and makes it go along the orbit as well

member.name: F:CelestialBody.orbitingBodies
member.summary: A list of this body's moons (or, in the case of the Sun, a list of the planets).

member.name: F:CelestialBody.pqsController
member.summary: The pqsController computes the terrain of the planet. Note that for the Sun, pqsController = null.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.Radius
member.summary: The radius of the planet in meters. Note that this is only the radius of "sea level"; the actual terrain may be higher.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.rotationPeriod
member.summary: The time, in seconds, for the body to complete one rotation around its axis

member.name: F:CelestialBody.sphereOfInfluence
member.summary: The radius of this body's sphere of influence (measured from the center of the body), in meters.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.tidallyLocked
member.summary: Presumably, whether this body is tidally locked to the body around with it orbits.

member.name: F:CelestialBody.timeWarpAltitudeLimits
member.summary: Presumably, this gives the minimum altitude you must have in order to be allowed to use each warp rate when in this body's sphere of influence.

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetAltitude(Vector3d)
member.summary: Gets the height of a given position above this body's sea level, in meters.

member.returns: Altitude in meters

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetFrameVel
member.summary: The velocity of the CelestialBody, {AliceWorld, Sun}. (See Orbit.cs for the reference frame definitions).

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetLatitude(Vector3d)
member.summary: Gets the latitude of a given position, in degrees.
member.param: A position in world coordinates
member.returns: Latitude in degrees

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetLongitude(Vector3d)
member.summary: Gets the longitude of a given position, in degrees. Note that you CANNOT count on this value being in any particular range. This function may for example return 420, meaning 60 degrees east. You would be well advised to coerce it into a standard range like -180 to 180 before using it.
member.param: A position in world coordinates
member.returns: Longitude in degrees

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetRelSurfacePosition(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a vector pointing from the center of the body to the given latitude, longitude, and altitude.
member.param: Latitude in degrees
Longitude in degrees
Altitude above sea level in meters
member.returns: A position vector relative to the center of the body

member.name: M:CelestialBody.getRFrmVel(Vector3d)
member.summary: Returns the velocity at a given position of the frame of reference that rotates with the planet. This velocity is the difference between the "orbit" and "surface" velocities.
member.param: A position in world coordinates
member.returns: Velocity of the rotating reference frame

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetSurfaceNVector(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a unit vector perpendicular to the surface of the body at the given latitude and longitude (pretending for the moment that the body is a perfect sphere).
member.param: Latitude in degrees
Longitude in degrees
member.returns: A unit normal vector to the surface

member.name: M:CelestialBody.GetWorldSurfacePosition(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns the position, in world coordinates, of a given latitude, longitude, and altitude
member.param: Latitude in degrees
Longitude in degrees
Altitude above sea level in meters
member.returns: Position in world coordinates

member.name: P:DiscoveryInfo.referenceLifetime
member.summary: The time for which an asteroid can go untracked if it starts at full signal strength Alternate definition: the time needed for the signal strength to fall by 1 unit. Always equals 86400 ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.maxUntrackedLifetime. For the default spawn settings, this is 1728000 seconds, or 20 Earth days. Stored in persistence file as refTime

member.name: P:DiscoveryInfo.unobservedLifetime
member.summary: The time for which the asteroid can go untracked before it is deleted Stored in persistence file as lifetime

member.summary: Returns the fraction of the asteroid's unobservedLifetime that remains
member.param: The time at which the signal life is measured
member.remarks: GetSignalLife(t_discover) == 1.0 GetSignalLife(fadeUT) == 0.0

member.name: M:DiscoveryInfo.GetSignalStrength(System.Double)
member.summary: Returns amount of time remaining until the asteroid is lost, in units of referenceLifetime
member.param: The time at which the signal strength is measured
member.remarks: GetSignalStrength(t_discover) == unobservedLifetime / referenceLifetime GetSignalStrength(fadeUT) == 0.0

member.name: T:GameEvents
member.summary: GameEvents are EventData or EventVoid methods called when certain conditions are met. Many include some relevant data on the objects affected when they are triggered. Use:
member.remarks: and

to add and remove methods from a list of methods to be called when the event is triggered. Methods are generally added in your object's Start or Awake method and generally removed in your object's OnDestroy method. Be sure not add methods multiple times withoud destroying them between additions.

member.name: F:GameEvents.OnProgressAchieved
member.summary: Triggered when a ProgressNode and all of its subNodes are completed. See also OnProgressReached and OnProgressComplete

member.name: F:GameEvents.OnProgressComplete
member.summary: Triggered when all sub ProgressNodes within a given ProgressNode are completed; records the UT of node completion and returns the ProgressNode See the ProgressTracking module in the persistent.sfs file for more on how ProgressNodes are setup and saved. If the ProgressNode is completed upon first achievement this will also trigger OnProgressReached. See also OnProgressReached and OnProgressAchieved

member.name: F:GameEvents.OnProgressReached
member.summary: Triggered when a ProgressNode is first reached but not completed; records the UT of node achievement and returns the ProgressNode. For instance, when a vessels first enters the SOI of a new Celestial Body the event will trigger and a "reached" entry will be added to the persistent.sfs file. If a ProgressNode is completed at the same time it is reached (ie has no ProgressNode subNodes) OnProgressCompelete will be triggered at the same time See the ProgressTracking module in the persistent.sfs file for more on how ProgressNodes are setup and saved. See also OnProgressComplete and OnProgressAchieved

member.name: T:GamePersistence
member.summary: Contains some functions you can call to save the game state to a persistence file, or load the game state from a persistence file.

member.name: M:GamePersistence.SaveGame(string,string,SaveMode)
member.summary:
Creates a persistence file containing the current game state.
SaveGame(string, string, SaveMode) calls SaveGame(HighLogic.CurrentGame.Updated(), string, string, SaveMode) (or creates CurrentGame if it doesn't exist).
member.param: The name of the persistence file to create (".sfs" will be appended automatically to the file name).
The folder in which to create the save file. Use HighLogic.SaveFolder to acquire the default one for the current game.
Whether to overwrite, append, or abort if the given file already exists.
member.returns: Returns the filename on success. Returns an empty string when the file already exists and SaveMode.ABORT is used.

member.name: M:GamePersistence.SaveGame(Game,string,string,SaveMode)
member.summary: For creating a savegame at the space center, simply use SaveGame(string, string, SaveMode) instead. For quicksaves call Updated() on CurrentGame to get a Game, then reset that Game's startScene to FLIGHT, and then call SaveGame(Game, string, string, SaveMode).
member.param: The game for which you want to create a save file.
The name of the persistence file to create (".sfs" will be appended to the file name).
The folder in which to create the save file. Use HighLogic.SaveFolder to acquire the default one for the current game.
Whether to overwrite, append, or abort if the given file already exists.
member.returns: Returns the filename on success. Returns an empty string when the file already exists and SaveMode.ABORT is used.

member.name: T:KSP.IO.PluginConfiguration
member.summary: From N3X15: PluginConfiguration was something I threw together a while ago to try and improve settings serialization. The INI files we were using just couldn't cope with newlines and had all sorts of horrible workarounds. Instead of INI files, it writes structured XML files that look like this:

para.code: <config> <int name="int"\>4</int> <long name="long">45</long> <short name="short">4</short> <byte name="byte">255</byte> <bool name="bool">1</bool> <vector3 name="vector3"> <x>0</x> <y>1</y> <z>2</z> </vector3> <vector3d name="vector3d"> <x>0</x> <y>1</y> <z>2.05</z> </vector3d> <string name="string">string</string> </config>

member.para: Despite looking a bit messy, it's actually a lot easier to use and doesn't have as many drawbacks as INI files. Newlines are preserved, and most importantly, types are also preserved. Oh, and it's UTF-8 encoded, so internationalization won't be as much as a problem, theoretically. Here's how to use it:

para.code: PluginConfiguration cfg = PluginConfiguration.CreateForType<MyCoolModule>(); cfg["a string"] = "I love KSP!"; cfg["another setting"] = new Vector3d(0,1,2); cfg.save(); // Later... cfg.load(); settingAString = cfg.GetValue<string>("a string"); settingAVector = cfg.GetValue<Vector3d>("another setting");

member.summary: Add a MOD(3rd party) application to the Application Launcher. Use ApplicationLauncherButton.VisibleInScenes to set where the button should be displayed. Note that the application launcher is destroyed when the player exits to the main menu. If the player then loads up a new save the application launcher will be recreated and you will have to re-add your button. Register for GameEvents.onGUIApplicationLauncherDestroyed and GameEvents.onGUIApplicationLauncherReady to detect when the application launcher has been destroyed and when it has been re-created.

Callback for when the button is hidden or disabled by the application launcher
The "scenes" this button will be visible in. For example VisibleInScenes = ApplicationLauncher.AppScenes.FLIGHT | ApplicationLauncher.AppScenes.MAPVIEW;
The 38x38 PackedSprite animation to use for the button icon. Use ApplicationLauncherButton.PlayAnim() to play the animation.

member.name: M:KSP.UI.Screens.Flight.KerbalPortraitGallery.RegisterActiveCrew(Kerbal)
member.summary: Register a Kerbal crewmember to the Portrait Gallery. Beware this will duplicate portraits if the crewmember is already in the list. The list itself cannot be accessed as it is a private list. You can call UnRegisterActiveCrew before calling this. But that kind of defeats the purpose. The best bet is to attach to the portraitPrefab instance and build your own list. If you unregistered the kerbal previously and called kerbal.SetVisibleInPortrait(false) and set kerbal.inPart to null that you have to reverse this and set their inPart and SetVisibleInPortrait(true) before calling this method.

member.name: M:KSP.UI.Screens.Flight.KerbalPortraitGallery.UnregisterActiveCrew(Kerbal)
member.summary: UnRegister a Kerbal crewmember to the Portrait Gallery. They will respawn a portrait though unless you set the kerbal.inPart to null and set the kerbal.SetVisibleInPortrait(false) first. If you do this, don't forget to set the kerbal.SetVisibleInPortrait(true) before you ReigsterActiveCrew.

T:Krakensbane
member.summary: The physics simulation has problems if vessels move too fast relative to the underlying reference frame used by the simulation, or get too far from the origin of the coordinate system. Krakensbane shifts the reference frame origin and velocity so that the active vessel is always near the origin of, and moving slowly with respect to, the underlying coordinate system used by the physics simulation.

member.name: M:Krakensbane.setOffset(Vector3d)
member.summary: Moves all vessels not on rails by the given position offset. This will usually only affect the active vessel, unless there are other vessels nearby. The offset can be very large and the vessels will not break, unlike for Vessel.SetPosition.

member.name: T:Orbit
member.para: An Orbit class represents a Keplerian orbit. Each Vessel and each CelestialBody has an Orbit. CelestialBodies and on-rails Vessels follow their Orbits exactly. Off-rails vessels (the active vessel and any nearby vessels) do not follow their orbits exactly; instead their motion is computed frame-by-frame from the forces acting on them.
A patched consics trajectory consists of a series of Orbits, called patches.

This class uses multiple axes and reference frames to describe positions and velocities.
We call the choices of axes
World: world coordinates. Left-handed.
member.remarks: We use the concise notation {Axes, Frame} for describing the reference frame and axes used.</para>

member.name: F:Orbit.activePatch
member.summary: Whether this patch actually represents a real orbit patch in the projected flight path. Often Orbit.nextPatch for the last real will not be null, but will be some sort of bogus Orbit object. You can recognize these because activePatch will be false.

member.name: F:Orbit.argumentOfPeriapsis
member.summary: The angle between the ascending node and the periapsis, in degrees.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccentricAnomaly
member.summary: A quantity used in the math describing Keplerian orbits; Google it.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccentricity
member.summary: The eccentricity of the orbit.

member.name: F:Orbit.eccVec
member.summary: A vector that points toward periapsis, with mangitude equal to the eccentricity. NOTE: All Vector3d's returned by Orbit class functions have their y and z axes flipped. You have to flip these back to get the vectors in world coordinates.

member.name: F:Orbit.EndUT
member.summary: The universal time at which this patch ends.

member.name: F:Orbit.epoch
member.summary: A special UT at which the parameters of the Orbit are defined. See meanAnomalyAtEpoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.h
member.summary: The specific orbital angular momentum

member.name: F:Orbit.inclination
member.summary: The inclination of this orbit with respect to the equator of the central body in degrees

member.name: F:Orbit.LAN
member.summary: The longitude of the ascending node of the orbit, in degrees. The LAN is the angle between the ascending node and Planetarium.right, as viewed along Planetarium.up.

member.name: F:Orbit.meanAnomaly
member.summary: Mean anomaly is the fraction of the orbit that has been completed, measured starting from the periapsis, multiplied by 2. Look it up.

member.name: F:Orbit.meanAnomalyAtEpoch
member.summary: The mean anomaly of the orbit at the special UT given by Orbit.epoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.ObT
member.summary: Time since periapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.ObTAtEpoch
member.summary: The value of ObT at the universal time given by epoch.

member.name: F:Orbit.orbitPercent
member.summary: Equal to

member.name: F:Orbit.patchEndTransition
member.summary: How the next patch follows onto this one, or FINAL if there is no patch after this one.

member.name: F:Orbit.period
member.summary: The period of the orbit, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.pos
member.summary: The position of the orbiting object, {AliceWorld, Primary}.

member.name: F:Orbit.referenceBody
member.summary: The body orbited.

member.name: F:Orbit.semiMajorAxis
member.summary: The semi-major axis of the orbit, in meters. Equal to (PeR + ApR)/2

member.name: F:Orbit.timeToAp
member.summary: The time until the object will reach apoapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.timeToPe
member.summary: The time unti lthe object will reach periapsis, in seconds.

member.name: F:Orbit.vel
member.summary: The velocity of the orbiting object, {AliceWorld, Primary}.

member.name: P:Orbit.ApA
member.summary: The apoapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from sea level.

member.name: P:Orbit.ApR
member.summary: The apoapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from the center of the main body.

member.name: P:Orbit.PeA
member.summary: The periapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from sea level.

member.name: P:Orbit.PeR
member.summary: The periapsis of the orbit in meters, measured from the center of the main body.

member.summary: A property of ellipses, parabolas and hyperbolas; Google it.

member.name: P:Orbit.semiMinorAxis
member.summary: A property of ellipses; Google it.

member.name: M:Orbit.GetFrameVel
member.summary: The velocity of the orbiting object, {AliceWorld, Sun}.

member.summary: A unit vector normal to the plane of the orbit. NOTE: All Vector3d's returned by Orbit class functions have their y and z axes flipped. You have to flip these back to get the vectors in world coordinates.
member.returns: A unit normal vector.

member.name: M:Orbit.getRelativePositionAtT(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the predicted displacement of the orbiting object from the center of the main body at a given time since perigee passage. NOTE: All Vector3d's returned by Orbit class functions have their y and z axes flipped. You have to flip these back to get the vectors in world coordinates.

member.returns: Position relative to the main body (YZ flipped)

member.name: M:Orbit.getRelativePositionAtUT(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the predicted displacement of the orbiting object from the center of the main body at a given universal time. NOTE: All Vector3d's returned by Orbit class functions have their y and z axes flipped. You have to flip these back to get the vectors in world coordinates.
member.param: A univeral time.
member.returns: Position relative to the main body (YZ flipped)

member.name: M:Orbit.GetRotFrameVel(CelestialBody)
member.summary: The velocity of a hypothetical object, located where the orbiting object is, and at rest in the ConditionallyRotating[refBody] frame, {AliceWorld, BodyCentre[refBody]}. In other words, velocity of the ConditionallyRotating[refBody] frame in the BodyCentre[refBody] frame at the position of the orbiting object (AliceWorld axes). Note: this only depends on the orbital position, not on the orbital velocity.

member.summary: The true anomaly at which the orbiting object will achieve the given distance from the center of the main body.
member.param: Distance from the center of the main body, in meters.
member.returns: True anomaly, in radians.

member.summary: Updates this orbit to reflect the orbit that will be taken around the given body by an object with the given position and velocity at the given universal time.

member.summary: A unique identifier assigned to the part when the vessel it is a part of is created. All parts on the vessel get the same missionID and it does not change. Splitting a vessel with a decoupler will result with two vessels whose parts have the same missionID. When two vessels spawned seperately dock, each part keeps its original missionID, undocking does not change this field either.

member.name: M:PartModule.OnStart(PartModule+StartState)
member.summary:
Called when the flight starts, or when the part is created in the editor. OnStart will be called before OnUpdate or OnFixedUpdate are ever called.

member.remarks: instead of overriding OnFixedUpdate. See the Unity documentation on Update for more information. Poll for user input in OnUpdate, not OnFixedUpdate.

member.summary: Along with "up" and "forward," one of the three vectors defining the fixed celestial reference frame. The LAN (longitude of the ascending node) of every orbit is defined in reference to Planetarium.right. Specifically, the LAN is the angle between Planetarium.right and the orbit's ascending node, as viewed along Planetarium.up.

member.name: T:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects
member.summary: Stores information on asteroid spawning Executed while in Flight, Tracking Station, and Space Center scenes The module schedules periodic "spawn checks" while the game clock is running, at an interval set by spawnInterval. At each spawn check, any asteroids that have gone untracked for too long are removed from the game. To add an element of randomness, only a fraction of checks (controlled by spawnOddsAgainst) have a chance to produce asteroids. No asteroids are produced if the number of untracked asteroids already in the game exceeds spawnGroupMaxLimit. Because spawn checks happen very frequently, the number of detected asteroids in a game where the player never tracks an asteroid will almost always be close to spawnGroupMaxLimit.

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.maxUntrackedLifetime
member.summary: Longest time an asteroid can go untracked before disappearing, in Earth days

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.minUntrackedLifetime
member.summary: Shortest time an asteroid can go untracked before disappearing, in Earth days

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.sizeCurve
member.summary: Sets size distribution for asteroids The output range of [0, 1) is divided equally among the classes. So [0, 0.2) is class A, [0.2, 0.4) is class B, ..., [0.8, 1) is class E. Default curve translates to 12% class A, 13% class B, 49% class C, 13% class D, and 12% class E

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnGroupMaxLimit
member.summary: Number of untracked asteroids at which spawn rate stops completely

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnGroupMinLimit
member.summary: Number of untracked asteroids at which spawn rate begins to slow

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnInterval
member.summary: Number of seconds between asteroid checks These are approximately seconds of in-game time, but if you make sudden changes in the time warp rate the spawner may need some time to catch up. Since asteroids are removed during spawn checks, spawnInterval also controls the asteroid removal rate.

member.name: F:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.spawnOddsAgainst
member.summary: Controls the fraction of spawn checks in which new asteroids are generated The probability of spawning an asteroid is 1 / (1 + spawnOddsAgainst)

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.debugSpawnProbability
member.summary: Returns a description of the current spawn interval and spawn odds

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.SpawnAsteroid
member.summary: Creates a random asteroid and Kerbin-intercepting orbit

member.name: M:ScenarioDiscoverableObjects.SpawnLastAsteroid
member.summary: Creates a random asteroid and Kerbin-intercepting orbit.
member.remarks: Asteroid is identical to the last call of SpawnAsteroid()</seealso> Intended for debugging?

member.name: T:TutorialScenario
member.summary: A TutorialScenario is a ScenarioModule with some added features that are useful for building tutorials or similar kinds of scenarios. A TutorialScenario comes with a builtin in finite state machine for running the scenario and displays "tutorial pages" in a GUI window alongside a picture of a friendly Kerbal instructor. You can take advantage of all these features by making your ScenarioModule a subclass of TutorialScenario. See HarvesteR's example code in his forum article: http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/content.php/121-Writing-Tutorials-A-Demo-%28and-some-source-code%29

member.name: T:Vessel
member.summary: A Vessel object represents a single vessel. Parts that break off from a vessel become their own Vessels. Vessels that merge via docking become one Vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.acceleration
member.summary: Presumably, this is the current acceleration vector of the vessel, in m/s^2?

member.name: F:Vessel.altitude
member.summary: Presumably, this is the current altitude above sea of the vessel, in meters? Is equal to pqsAltitude + heightFromTerrain (where heightFromTerrain is not -1).

member.name: F:Vessel.angularMomentum
member.summary: Presumably, this is the current angular momentum of the vessel?

member.name: F:Vessel.angularVelocity
member.summary: The current angular velocity vector of the vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.atmDensity
member.summary: Presumably, this is the current density of the atmosphere at the vessel's position?

member.name: F:Vessel.CoM
member.summary: Presumably, this is the position of the center of mass of the vessel?

member.name: F:Vessel.ctrlState
member.summary: The set of flight inputs currently being fed to the vessel. For example the current throttle being applied to the vesesl is vessel.ctrlState.mainThrottle.

member.name: F:Vessel.evaController
member.summary: If the vessel is a Kerbal on EVA, this object contains most EVA related information

member.name: F:Vessel.heightFromSurface
member.summary: Appears to always be -1?

member.name: F:Vessel.heightFromTerrain
member.summary: The vertical distance in meters between the vessel and the nearest terrain (including buildings), or -1 when sea depth is greater than 600m (terrainAltitude <= -600). Once you are above roughly 42km above ground it turns to -1 again (only confirmed on Kerbin so far)

member.name: F:Vessel.horizontalSrfSpeed
member.summary: Presumably, the horizontal component of srf_velocity, in m/s.

member.name: F:Vessel.id
member.summary: A unique identifier assigned to a vessel. When two vessels dock, the combined vessel has the id of the vessel docked to. On undock, the vessel undocked from keeps its id, the vessel that undocks gets a new id. Note that this id is always fresh, a vessel gets a different id when it undocks then it had before docking. This is the pid value in the persistent.sfs at the VESSEL level.

member.name: F:Vessel.Landed
member.summary: Whether the vessel is currently sitting on the ground.

member.name: F:Vessel.latitude
member.summary: The current latitude of the vessel over the current mainBody, in degrees.

member.name: F:Vessel.launchTime
member.summary: The universal time at which the vessel was launched, in seconds?

member.name: F:Vessel.loaded
member.summary: Whether the vessel is currently loaded. Vessels are only loaded when they come within about 2.5km of the active vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.longitude
member.summary: The current longitude of the vessel over the current mainBody, in degrees

member.name: F:Vessel.missionTime
member.summary: Mission elapsed time, in seconds, maybe?

member.name: F:Vessel.obt_velocity
member.summary: The current velocity of the vessel, in world coordinates, in the nonrotating inertial reference frame.

member.name: F:Vessel.OnFlyByWire
member.summary: You can add your own function to this callback to register a function that can provide flight control input to the vessel. Once you've registered this callback, it will be called once per FixedUpdate. Provide flight control input by modifying the FlightCtrlState passed to your function. This FlightCtrlState will already contain the player's input, which you can modify or override as desired.
member.example: void MyAutopilotFunction(FlightCtrlState s) { s.yaw = 1; } ... vessel.OnFlyByWire += MyAutopilotFunctionThis will create an autopilot that always yaws hard to the right. You can probably devise something more useful, though...

member.name: F:Vessel.OnJustAboutToBeDestroyed
member.summary: You can add a function to this callback, and the function will be called when the vessel is "just about to be destroyed."

member.name: F:Vessel.orbitDriver
member.summary: This is the 'parent' container for everything to do with the vessels orbit, use OrbitDriver.orbit to find and set information about the vessel orbit.

member.name: F:Vessel.packed
member.summary: Whether the vessel is currently packed. Vessels are only packed when the come within about 300m of the active vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.parts
member.summary: A list of the parts in the vessel. Note that when the vessel is not loaded, this list will be empty.

member.name: F:Vessel.patchedConicSolver
member.summary: Among other things, the patchedConicSolver stores information about the player's current set of maneuver nodes.

member.name: F:Vessel.pqsAltitude
member.summary: Presumably, the height in meters of the planet's terrain QuadSphere directly under the vessel, compared to sea level. This does not take the height of buildings into account. It is generally within +/- 1m of terrainAltitude, except when over buildings (terrainAltitude does account for buildings) or sea with a depth of greater than 600m (terrainAltitude <= -600, heightFromTerrain == -1).

member.name: F:Vessel.protoVessel
member.summary: The protoVessel can be used to get some saved information about unloaded vessels.

member.name: F:Vessel.referenceTransformId
member.summary: This is the flightID of the part that is the current 'Control from Here' part. This is the root part until changed by the player. The vessel transform is set to the transform of this part. This is the 'ref' value in the persistent.sfs at the VESSEL level.

member.name: F:Vessel.rootPart
member.summary: The root of the tree of parts that comprises the vessel. Usually this is the original command pod placed when constructing the vessel.

member.name: F:Vessel.situation

member.name: F:Vessel.Splashed

member.name: F:Vessel.srf_velocity
member.summary: The velocity of the vessel in the "surface" reference frame, the reference frame that rotates with the planet.

member.name: F:Vessel.staticPressurekPa

member.name: F:Vessel.terrainAltitude
member.summary: The height in meters of the nearest terrain (including buildings) directly under the vessel, compared to sea level. Ground which is underwater will have a negative terrainAltitude.

member.name: F:Vessel.verticalSpeed
